text: hey everyone Anthony Fantana here
Internet's busiest music nerd and it is
time for a review of the new young
fathers LP dead before we get too deep
into this album as I know a lot of you
like to do you like to point out as soon
as there's some kind of significant
major change or alteration and anything
that occurs in these videos on a regular
basis and let's just get out of the way
now yes couch' chesta is wearing a
backwards baseball cap it's not a big
deal
who cares these guys are an eclectic
hip-hop trio that hail from Scotland I
first stumbled upon their sound in early
2012 just a few months after they
dropped their debut mixtape EP album
tape 1 that was released late 2011 on
this tape African music reggae and lo-fi
electronics all mixed together into this
really soulful and gritty take on hip
hop music they followed this release up
with assigning to anti Cohn records they
dropped the sequel to tape 1 tape 2 last
year
musically sonically it was really a
continuation of a lot of what was going
on with tape 1 except maybe the ballads
on this tape or a little bit more
beautiful soulful like the opener on
this thing and there were more explosive
tracks on here too like Queen is dead my
only major issue with these tapes is
that they were sort of brief I thought
young fathers were we're writing really
fantastically catchy songs but I also
couldn't help but feel like they were
sort of holding back in terms of the
length of their overall projects holding
back from something with just a bit more
runtime and a lot more ambition I also
suspected that coming out with music on
anti Khan Records would mean that future
releases would be a little bit more well
recorded - and on this latest LP of
there's young fathers pretty much show
improvements on all of these fronts once
the first looking from this LP dropped
low I was incredibly excited to hear
where young fathers would move next this
song has got a beautiful intro really
poetic lyrics great singing to meet
young fathers is one of the best groups
out there that makes hip hop music that
also features this much good passionate
soulful singing and once the beat to
this track kicks in and
old's it sounds more like a parade of
drummers than it does any sort of
traditional hip-hop beat that's produced
on a laptop or a sampler and the vocal
harmonies on this song and other songs
on here too sound much more concise well
put together really cleaned up nicely
young fathers hit the nail on the head
every time when it comes to this group
singing or chanting that they do on
their tracks
there's loads of off-kilter and sort of
quirky and noisy sense on this record
too as well as weird colorful sound
effects that hang in the background sort
of a noisy ambience to either the drums
or the vocals I feel like young fathers
did a great job of advancing their sound
improving it making it sound nicer while
carrying over most of the
characteristics from their previous
tapes all of that being said why is it
that I'm not in love with this album why
is it not that I'm completely head over
heels for it and because I'm not
honestly for me it comes down to two
things one the instrumentals on this LP
are some of the most redundant and
repetitive that young fathers have put
together so far and some of the songs on
this record I think are some of the most
lackluster that they've put out to the
instrumentals on this LP show very
little change from the beginning to the
end of the track the really quirky
keyboards and primal drums that main
tape one and tape two so great go really
stale really quickly as they repeat the
same phrases over and over and over and
over across verses and choruses that
don't really have that much contrast
from one another this happens on
numerous tracks paying I've arrived
hangman just another bullet and even the
song get up which is easily the
catchiest track on this entire LP but
even the really infectious chorus
doesn't draw away from the fact that the
rhythm section feels so redundant this
is actually a difficult thing for me to
come to terms with when listening to
this record because this is the last
thing that I thought I would feel while
listening to the tracks on dead given
that the recording quality on dead is
better than that of the last two tapes
I would only assume that it would be
easier for young fathers to write more
dynamic songs with very subtle lows
of highs but it just doesn't happen
there are plenty of tracks on this LP
where the vocals feel particularly
beautiful or intense like the screaming
on the track paying or the really
soulful singing on the song dip but
instrumentally dead feels way too mid
paced and too mild to be as exciting as
anything young fathers have done so far
I think the only visceral spot for me on
this entire LP was the opening track no
way with the hammering kick drums at the
very end of the song and like I said
before I do think there are some songs
on here that are sort of lacking as well
the song am I not your boy a beautiful
tune really great ballad on here but a
song that I think really could have done
with a climax
there's the song get up that I already
mentioned that while it is the catchiest
song on the entire LP maybe because the
refrain is repeated so liberally but
lyrically it's not really one of the
more gripping songs that young fathers
have have pulled together there's only
one real track on here that I outright
disliked and really let me down and
that's mm-hmm a song that moves into
really strange sonic territory with an
abstract song structure and is really
spacious and just does not end up
engaging because of that you know
majority of the songs on here aren't
terrible but they just don't go that
step further to really wow me there are
some songs on here though where I really
do love the lyrical imagery like on dip
and no way and especially low did I see
you planting seeds in the forest is it
for the green or the dollars now don't
go telling me it's for the needs of the
poorest now I'm going to take a [ __ ] in
your palace the imagery on the song war
is really vivid as well and am I not
your boy is a sort of interesting song
that seems to be written with a mother
in mind and it's sort of confessional in
a way telling her that the boy that you
once were is dead now many of the songs
do have gripping nice characteristics
and I think young fathers have
maintained their personality over the
course of making this album as well I
mean there aren't any groups out there
that I can really name that have a sound
quite like young fathers but the biggest
hindrance to this LP is that there's
just not a lot of variation to these
the better sound and the better singing
on this LP do balance out what I don't
like about it in a sense but really dead
is a step down for me in terms of
memorability and enjoyability I'm
feeling a light to decent six on this
thing transition if you've given this LP
listen what did you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why did you feel
either and what should I review next
young fathers dead forever
